CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 18;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . At the material time , the applicant was the owner and editor of a DATE review entitled Haberde Yorumda Gerçek ( ORG and Comments ) , published in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the seizure of the CARDINAL edition of the review , dated DATE , on the ground that an article therein entitled PERSON contained separatist propaganda . The article read :
“ PERSON ulusun toptan yok edilmesini izliyoruz . PERSON soykırım izliyoruz PERSON , bugüne kadar başka örneği görülmemiş desek yanlış olmaz .

PERSON savaşın dişlileri arasında inim inim inliyoruz . Savaşa karşı çıkmak gerektiğini bildiğimiz halde öfkemizi haykırmak , kirli savaş dişlilerini parçalamak yerine inim inim inliyoruz . Ağıt yakıyoruz sadece . PERSON övgü dizmeye çalışıyoruz ölüm sessizliğinde . GPE esintisinden , yaprak hışırtısından odalarımıza korku taşınıyor . Yüreklerimiz hop oturup hop kalkıyor . Ölüm korkusunda ölüme övgüler dizerken devlete teslim oluyoruz .

PERSON esintisinde sıcak çaylarımızı yudumlarken yürüttüğümüz hararetli tartışmalarımızda , kavgacı kesiliyoruz birden . GPE kaderlerini tayin hakkı diyoruz . Bu hakkın kullanılması önünde hiçbir engelin olmaması gerektiğinden söz ediyoruz . PERSON realitesinin tanınmasının önemli bir adım olduğunu açıklamaya çalışıyoruz . Ortadoğu’da savaşın nedeni NORP emperyalizmidir . Ve biz savaşa karşı çıkmanın insanlığın bir gereği olduğunu düşünüyoruz . Namaz dağları , PERSON ve ORG ve daha niceleri bombalanıyor bu sırada . GPE alev alev yanıyor . PERSON hızıyla sürüyor . PERSON ekranlardan Bosna’da yaşanan vahşeti izliyoruz .

PERSON birden . İnsan hakları savunucusu kesiliyoruz . Kimyasal silahlar kullanılıyor ORG dağlarında . “ PERSON üstünde taş bırakmayacağız ” diyor askeri yetkili . PERSON ulusu toptan yoketme isteklerindeki kararlılık çınlıyor kulaklarımızda . “ PERSON değil batıda da operasyonların sürdürüleceğini , teröristlere yardımcı olanların haklarından gelineceğini ” ekliyor konuşmasına ve tabii basının kulağını çekmeyi de ihmal etmiyor . İşte burada , bir kirli savaşın söylemlerimizdeki yenilgiye mahkum akibetini , savaşa karşı çıkmanın tek ama tek yolunun haklı savaşın yürütülmesi gerektiği doğrusunu unutuyoruz . Unutmak istiyoruz . Tendürek’e düşen bomba , yüreğimizde patlıyor . “ NORP ” diyor içimizden biri . “ PERSON kanın dökülmesi ORG ? Kürt ve Türk ulusları kardeş değil mi ? ” diye ekleyerek başlıyor bilinen konuşmasına .

Hep bu konuşmayı bekliyormuşuz da , birbirimizden haberimiz yokmuş meğer . Her birimiz ayrı ayrı ve sanki farklı şeyler söylüyormuşuz gibi korkularımızı açığa vuruyoruz . ORG DATE hizmetinde kusur etmemeye itina gösteriyoruz . Türk şovenizminin asla onaylanmadığını ama , ORG onaylanamayacağını anlatıyoruz hep bir ağızdan . Ezilen ulusun şovenizminin olmayacağını bile bile lades yapmaya çalışıyoruz . Kürt meselesinin çözümünde barışçıl yolların denenmesi gerektiğini vaaz ediyor , çözümün ne olabileceğini tartışıyoruz , büyük pişkinlikle .

ORG sayfalarını ORG yaylasını basan “ teröristlerin ” , kadınları , çocukları ORG öldürdüklerini anlatan düzmece haberlerle dolduruyoruz . PERSON verilen brifingden kamuoyunun bilgisi olmadığı bilgisizliğiyle köşe yazılarımızda Kürt ve Türk vatandaşların yüzyıllar boyunca kardeşçe bir arada yaşadığını , oysa “ teröristlerin ” emellerinin bu kardeşliği yıkmak olduğunu anlatıyoruz demokratça ! PERSON özgürlük yürüyüşüne geçen Kürt köylüsünün tavrına .
Biz aydın insanlarız . ORG elden bırakmayız . PERSON ölmüş ? PERSON hizmeti de esas alırız . GPE aptal biliriz . PERSON mürekkep yalamışlığımız bizi onlardan farklı kılar .
Bu bir itiraftır .
Biz aptalız . ”

“ We are watching the wholesale extermination of a nation . We are watching a genocide on such a scale that it is not a mistake to call it unprecedented .

We are groaning between the cogwheels of a dirty war . We know we should take a stand against the war , but instead of shouting out our anger and smashing the cogwheels , we are groaning . We only wail . We try to praise death in the deathly silence . Fear seeps into our rooms from the whisper of the breeze and the rustle of leaves . Our hearts jump in our throats . We surrender to the ORG while we praise death in fear of death .

We suddenly become quarrelsome during our feverish discussions and while sipping our hot tea in the cool breeze of the air conditioner . We talk about the right to selfdetermination of nations . We are saying that there should be no impediment to the exercise of this right . We try to explain that recognition of NORP reality is an important step . The reason for war in the middle - east is NORP imperialism and we think that to stand up against this war is a requirement for being a human being . The Namaz mountains , the Tendürek , the ORG and many others are being bombed at this moment . GPE is blazing . The genocide pounds on . We watch the terror in GPE on our colour TV screens .

Suddenly we are full of anger . We become human rights advocates . Chemical weapons are being used on the ORG mountains . ‘ We will not leave a stone ORG says a military authority . Their determination to exterminate a whole nation echoes in our ears . ‘ ORG will be conducted not only in the south - east but also in the west . We ’ll deal with the people who help the ORG he adds , and of course makes sure to tip off the press . Here we forget that in our own words a dirty war can only end in defeat . We [ also ] forget the axiom that the only way to oppose a war is to wage a just war . We want to forget it . The bomb falling on ORG explodes in our hearts . ‘ What a pity’ says CARDINAL of us . ‘ Why shed so much blood ? Are n’t NORP and NORP nations brothers?’ And he begins his usual speech .

We seem to have been waiting for that speech all the time , but we were not aware of one another . We each confess our fears as if we are saying different things . We take great care to serve the army officer faultlessly . We chorus that we have never approved of NORP chauvinism but can not approve of NORP chauvinism either . We turn a blind eye to the fact that an oppressed nation can not be chauvinistic . We brazenly preach the necessity of trying peaceful methods to resolve the NORP problem and discuss what the solution might be .

We fill the pages of our newspapers with bogus news of the ORG raid on the ORG plateau and details of how they killed women and children . Oblivious of the fact that the public at large knows nothing of the briefing given to the press , we democratically explain in our newspaper columns that NORP and NORP citizens have lived together in brotherhood for DATE and that the terrorists’ aim is to undermine that brotherhood . And we denigrate the attitude of the NORP peasants who started a freedom march .

We are intellectuals . We shall not give up the NORP ’s way of life . But who ever died of a lie ? We also make it our rule to serve the ORG . We consider people stupid . Our many years of ink - licking make us different from them .
This is a confession .
We are stupid . ”

CARDINAL . In an indictment dated DATE ORG at ORG ( GPE PERSON ) charged the applicant with having disseminated propaganda against the indivisibility of the ORG by publishing the above article . The charges were brought under section CARDINAL of the Prevention of Terrorism Act DATE ( hereinafter “ the DATE LAW ” , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In the proceedings before ORG , the applicant denied the charges . She pleaded that the article did not contain separatist propaganda . She alleged that the institution of criminal proceedings against her , as the owner and the responsible editor , was aimed at punishing the review since no investigation was opened against the author of the impugned article whose picture appeared above it . The applicant referred to LAW and argued that section CARDINAL of the DATE Act restricted her right to freedom of expression in contravention of both LAW and LAW .

CARDINAL . In a judgment dated DATE ORG , composed of CARDINAL judges including a military judge , found the applicant guilty of an offence under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act . The court sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment and a fine of MONEY ( “ TRL ” ) , to be paid in CARDINAL DATE instalments . It also ordered confiscation of the offending publication .

CARDINAL . In its reasoning , the court held that the impugned article had referred to a certain part of NORP territory as “ GPE ” , had asserted that people living there were NORP citizens , that the NORP nation wanted to be exterminated , that genocide had taken place , that the territory defined as “ NORP ” had been bombed and burned and that chemical weapons had been used . On these grounds , the court found that the article , as a whole , disseminated propaganda against the indivisibility of the ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed against her conviction . On DATE ORG dismissed her appeal . It upheld ORG assessment of the evidence and its reasons for rejecting the applicant ’s defence . On DATE the judgment was served on the applicant .

CARDINAL . Following the amendments made by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE to the DATE LAW see paragraph CARDINAL below ) ; ORG ex officio re - examined the applicant ’s case . On DATE the court imposed the same sentence on the applicant . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment of DATE on the ground that ORG had not commuted the applicant ’s sentence of imprisonment to a fine .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to defer the imposition of a final sentence pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE . The court held , under section CARDINAL of the same law , that the criminal proceedings against the applicant would be suspended and a final sentence imposed should the applicant be convicted of a further intentional offence in her capacity as an editor within DATE of this decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG also found the author of the impugned article , PERSON , guilty of an offence under LAW § CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act . It sentenced him to DATE , DATE and CARDINAL days’ imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL GPE . However , the court suspended the author ’s sentence taking into account his good conduct in the past , the likelihood that he would not commit any further offence and the fact that he was not a recidivist .
CARDINAL . A full description of the relevant domestic law may be found in the NORP ( No . CARDINAL ) v. GPE judgment ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , ORG ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Prevention of Terrorism Act DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) creates the offence of undermining the territorial integrity of GPE or the indivisible unity of the nation through written and spoken propaganda , meetings , assemblies and demonstrations , irrespective of the methods used and the intention . Any person who engages in such an activity may be sentenced to imprisonment or a fine , which for a press editor nowadays may be up to DATE imprisonment and a fine of MONEY .

CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL of DATE amended LAW DATE to require the re - examination of the cases of persons convicted under the aforementioned LAW with a view to imposing substitute penalties or measures to imprisonment . Editors who had been convicted before DATE of a Section CARDINAL offence were later entitled to a suspended sentence for DATE , provided that no further offences were committed , pursuant to PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW requires all judges to perform their duties independently . ORG were established by LAW to try offences “ against the territorial integrity of the ORG or the indivisible unity of the nation or against the free democratic system of government , and offences which directly affect the ORG ’s internal or external security . ”

CARDINAL . According to Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL on the creation and rules of procedure of ORG , such courts shall be composed of a president , CARDINAL other regular members and CARDINAL substitute members , appointed for DATE renewable periods . At the material time , CARDINAL regular member and CARDINAL substitute were military judges of the first rank .
CARDINAL . Appeals lie to ORG against ORG decisions .

CARDINAL . NORP The careers of military judges , according to LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL ) , depend on assessments by the Minister of ORG in ORG , or PERSON . Section CARDINAL of that LAW provides that military judges are to be appointed “ by a committee composed of the personnel director and the legal adviser of ORG , the personnel director and the legal adviser attached to the staff of the arm in which the person concerned is serving and ORG at ORG … . ” It is an offence under LAW for a public official to attempt to influence the performance by a military judge in the exercise of his judicial functions . Military judges are subject to officer salary scales and discipline by ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . Career disputes concerning military judges are ultimately determined by ORG ( Section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE of DATE on ORG ) .
CARDINAL . Amendments made by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE and PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE removed military judges from the bench of ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant alleged that the authorities had unjustifiably interfered with her right to freedom of expression guaranteed by LAW , which provides :

“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to freedom of expression . This right shall include freedom to hold opinions and to receive and impart information and ideas without interference by public authority and regardless of frontiers . This Article shall not prevent GPE from requiring the licensing of broadcasting , television or cinema enterprises .

CARDINAL . The exercise of these freedoms , since it carries with it duties and responsibilities , may be subject to such formalities , conditions , restrictions or penalties as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a NORP society , in the interests of national security , territorial integrity or public safety , for the prevention of disorder or crime , for the protection of health or morals , for the protection of the reputation or rights of others , for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence , or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary . ”

CARDINAL . The Government maintained that the interference with the applicant ’s right to freedom of expression was justified under the provisions of the second paragraph of LAW . However , the ORG accepted the applicant ’s allegation .

CARDINAL . The ORG notes that it is clear and undisputed that there has been an interference with the applicant ’s right to freedom of expression on account of her conviction and sentence under section CARDINAL of the Prevention of Terrorism Act DATE ( the “ CARDINAL Act ” ) .

CARDINAL . This interference would contravene LAW unless it was “ prescribed by law ” , pursued CARDINAL or more of the legitimate aims referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , and was “ necessary in a NORP society ” for achieving such aim or aims . The ORG will examine each of these criteria in turn .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not comment on whether this requirement had been respected .
CARDINAL . The Government maintained that the measures taken against the applicant were based on section CARDINAL of the DATE Act .
CARDINAL . The Commission agreed with the ORG and found that the interference was prescribed by law .

CARDINAL . The ORG , like the Commission , finds that since the applicant ’s conviction was based on section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL LAW the resultant interference with her freedom of expression could be regarded as “ prescribed by law ” , all the more as the applicant has not disputed this ( see , in this connection , Sürek ( No . CARDINAL ) v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § DATE , ORG ORG ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not express a view on this point .
CARDINAL . The Government contended that the aim of the interference in issue had been to maintain “ national security ” and “ public safety ” . The ORG accepted this view .

CARDINAL . The ORG considers that , having regard to the sensitivity of the security situation in south - east GPE ( see the above - mentioned PERSON ( No.CARDINAL ) v. GPE judgment , § CARDINAL ) and to the need for the authorities to be alert to acts capable of fuelling additional violence , the measures taken against the applicant can be said to have been in furtherance of certain of the aims mentioned by the Government , namely the protection of national security and public safety . This is certainly true where , as with the situation in southeast GPE at the time of the circumstances of this case , the separatist movement had recourse to methods which relied on the use of violence .

CARDINAL . The applicant pleaded that she should not have been punished for an article which she had not written . She further contended that the impugned article praised democracy and human rights and suggested that intellectuals should be more courageous in defending the latter . She maintained that the article did not advocate recourse to terrorism and violence but , on the contrary , it criticised the waging of terrorism against people . In the applicant ’s submission the measures taken against her amounted to an unjustified and disproportionate interference with her LAW right .

CARDINAL . The Government asserted that the applicant disseminated separatist propaganda since the article in issue encouraged terrorist violence against the ORG . In support of their assertion the Government highlighted certain extracts from the article and contended that the phrase , “ we forget the axiom that the only way to oppose a war is to wage a just war ” was a clear incitement and encouragement to violence . In the ORG ’s submission , the author criticised intellectuals for defining “ innocent NORP peasants ” as “ terrorists ” and denigrating their march to freedom .

In the Government ’s opinion , the message which the article conveyed was that the only means for resolving the NORP problem was the maintenance of terrorist activities against the ORG , and that intellectuals should give the necessary support to such activities . The ORG argued that , in the context of a virulent terrorism campaign , the applicant should have refrained from disseminating propaganda aimed at supporting terrorist violence . They further submitted that the applicant had rightly been convicted under section CARDINAL of the DATE Act and that the measures taken against her properly fell within the authorities’ margin of appreciation in this area . The interference was accordingly justified under LAW .

The Government finally pointed out that the imposition of the final sentence on the applicant had been suspended , following the enactment of PERSON no . DATE of DATE , which aimed at providing for more lenient sanctions for offences committed through the medium of the press .

CARDINAL . The Commission noted that the incriminated publication was an article by an intellectual whose statements contained sharp criticism of the policy and action of GPE with regard to its population of NORP origin . The author expressed his view on the NORP question and did not associate himself with the use of violence in the context of the NORP separatist movement . In the ORG ’s view , the measures taken against the applicant amounted to a kind of censorship , which was likely to discourage others from publishing similar opinions in the future . On this basis , the ORG found that there had been a violation of LAW .

CARDINAL . The ORG recalls that in its PERSON v. GPE judgment of DATE ( Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-VII , pp . DATE , § DATE ) and the above - mentioned NORP ( CARDINAL ) v. GPE judgment ( cited above , § MONEY ) , it summarised the basic principles established in its case - law concerning LAW :

( i ) Freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundations of a NORP society and one of the basic conditions for its progress and for each individual ’s self - fulfilment . Subject to paragraph DATE , it is applicable not only to “ information ” or “ ideas ” that are favourably received or regarded as inoffensive or as a matter of indifference , but also to those that offend , shock or disturb . Such are the demands of that pluralism , tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no “ democratic society ” . As set forth in LAW , this freedom is subject to exceptions , which must , however , be construed strictly , and the need for any restrictions must be established convincingly .

( ii ) The adjective “ necessary ” , within the meaning of LAW , implies the existence of a “ pressing social need ” . GPE have a certain margin of appreciation in assessing whether such a need exists , but it goes hand in hand with NORP supervision , embracing both the legislation and the decisions applying it , even those given by an independent court . The ORG is therefore empowered to give the final ruling on whether a “ restriction ” is reconcilable with freedom of expression as protected by LAW .

( iii ) In exercising its supervisory jurisdiction , the ORG must look at the interference in the light of the case as a whole , including the content of the impugned statements and the context in which they were made . In particular , it must determine whether the interference in issue was “ proportionate to the legitimate aims pursued ” and whether the reasons adduced by the national authorities to justify it are “ relevant and sufficient ” .

The ORG notes in this connection that the nature and severity of the penalties imposed are also factors to be taken into account when assessing the proportionality of the interference ( see the Ceylan v. GPE judgment [ ORG ] , no . ORG , § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL-IV ) . In doing so , the ORG has to satisfy itself that the national authorities applied standards which were in conformity with the principles embodied in LAW and , moreover , that they based themselves on an acceptable assessment of the relevant facts .

CARDINAL . The ORG further observes that in the above - mentioned LANGUAGE ( No . CARDINAL ) v. GPE judgment ( § CARDINAL ) it reiterated that there is little scope under LAW § CARDINAL of the Convention for restrictions on political speech or on debate on questions of public interest . Furthermore , the limits of permissible criticism are wider with regard to the government than in relation to a private citizen , or even a politician . In a democratic system the actions or omissions of the government must be subject to the close scrutiny not only of the legislative and judicial authorities but also of public opinion .

Moreover , the dominant position which a government occupies makes it necessary for it to display restraint in resorting to criminal proceedings , particularly where other means are available for replying to the unjustified attacks and criticisms of its adversaries . Nevertheless , it certainly remains open to the competent ORG authorities to adopt , in their capacity as guarantors of public order , measures , even of a criminal - law nature , intended to react appropriately and without excess to such remarks ( see the GPE v. GPE judgment of DATE , Reports CARDINAL-IV , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) . Finally , where such remarks incite people to violence , the ORG authorities enjoy a wider margin of appreciation when examining the need for an interference with freedom of expression .

CARDINAL . Since the applicant was convicted of disseminating separatist propaganda through the review of which she was the editor , the impugned interference must also be seen in the context of the essential role of the press in ensuring the proper functioning of a political democracy ( see among many other authorities , the PERSON v. GPE judgment of DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , and the abovementioned Sürek ( No . CARDINAL ) judgment , § CARDINAL ) . While the press must not overstep the bounds set , inter alia , for the protection of vital ORG interests , such as national security or territorial integrity , against the threat of violence or the prevention of disorder or crime , it is nevertheless incumbent on the press to impart information and ideas on political issues , including divisive ones . Not only has the press the task of imparting such information and ideas , the public has a right to receive them . Freedom of the press affords the public one of the best means of discovering and forming an opinion of the ideas and attitudes of political leaders ( see the abovementioned PERSON judgment , p. CARDINAL § § , CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG stresses that the “ duties and responsibilities ” which accompany the exercise of the right to freedom of expression by media professionals assume special significance in situations of conflict and tension . Particular caution is called for when consideration is being given to the publication of views which contain incitement to violence against the ORG lest the media become a vehicle for the dissemination of hate speech and the promotion of violence . At the same time , where such views can not be so categorised , ORG can not , with reference to the protection of territorial integrity or national security or the prevention of crime or disorder , restrict the right of the public to be informed of them by bringing the weight of the criminal law to bear on the media ( see the ORG and PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL-IV ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG takes into account , furthermore , the background to cases submitted to it , particularly problems linked to the prevention of terrorism ( see PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § DATE ) . On that point , it takes note of the NORP authorities’ concern about the dissemination of views which they consider might exacerbate the serious disturbances that have been going on in GPE for DATE .

CARDINAL . The ORG notes that the applicant ’s review published an article which had been written by an intellectual who had expressed his views on the NORP problem . The impugned article contained a sharp criticism of the ORG ’s policy and of the action of their security forces with regard to the population of NORP origin . While alleging that intellectuals and the NORP press are denigrating the “ NORP peasants’ freedom march ” , the author criticised their overall view of the NORP problem . The author further suggested that the NORP reality should be recognised and peaceful methods tried in order to resolve the NORP problem instead of having recourse to military action . He regretted the shedding of blood in the course of armed conflict between NORP and NORP , since he considered them brother nations . He also expressed his disapproval of all types of chauvinism , including NORP and NORP forms .

CARDINAL . The ORG notes in addition that , although certain phrases seem aggressive in tone , such as the one highlighted by the Government , the article taken as a whole does not glorify violence . Nor does it incite people to hatred , revenge , recrimination or armed resistance . On the contrary , the article is an intellectual analysis of the NORP problem which calls for an end to the armed conflict . In the ORG ’s view these are the essential factors which should be considered ( see the PERSON v. GPE judgment , cited above , § CARDINAL ) .

Furthermore , the ORG observes that the applicant was convicted by ORG not for incitement to violence , but for disseminating separatist propaganda by referring to a particular region of GPE as “ NORP ” and alleging that the population of NORP origin living in that region was subjected to oppression . In this regard , the ORG considers that the domestic authorities in the instant case failed to give sufficient weight to the public ’s right to be informed of a different perspective on the situation in south - east GPE , irrespective of how unpalatable that perspective may be for them . As noted above , the views expressed in the incriminated article can not be read as an incitement to violence , nor could they be construed as liable to incite violence . That being so , the reasons given by ORG for convicting the applicant , although relevant , can not be considered sufficient to justify the interference with her right to freedom of expression .

CARDINAL . The ORG also observes that , notwithstanding the fact that the imposition of a final sentence on the applicant was suspended , she was nevertheless faced with the threat of a heavy penalty ( see the ORG and PERSON v. GPE judgment , cited above , § CARDINAL ) . For ORG , a decision or measure favourable to an applicant is not sufficient in principle to deprive him of his status as a “ victim ” unless the national authorities have acknowledged , either expressly or in substance , and then afforded redress for , the breach of the Convention ( see the GPE v. GPE judgment [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § DATE , ORG CARDINAL-VI ) .

In the instant case , however , ORG suspended the imposition of a final sentence on the applicant on condition that she did not commit any further offence as an editor within DATE of its decision ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . If the applicant fails to comply with that condition , she will automatically be sentenced for the original offence . In other words , the decision in question did not remove her status as a “ victim ” . On the contrary , the conditional suspended sentence had the effect of restricting the applicant ’s work as an editor and reducing her ability to offer the public views which have their place in a public debate whose existence can not be denied ( see , ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § DATE , to be published in DATE ; see also , mutatis mutandis , the ORG v. GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Reports CARDINAL-VI , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Having regard to the above considerations , the applicant ’s conviction was disproportionate to the aims pursued and , accordingly , not “ necessary in a democratic society ” . There has therefore been a violation of LAW .

CARDINAL . The applicant complained that the presence of a military judge on the bench of ORG which tried and convicted her meant that she was denied a fair hearing , in breach of LAW , the relevant part of which provides :
“ In the determination of ... any criminal charge against him , everyone is entitled to a fair ... hearing ... by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law ... ”
CARDINAL . The Government contested that allegation whereas the ORG accepted it .

CARDINAL . In the applicant ’s submission , under the rules applicable at the time , the military judges appointed to ORG , such as ORG , were dependent on the Executive and the army as regards their appointment and careers . Such ties made it impossible for military judges to discharge their functions on the bench in an independent and impartial manner . The applicant further stressed that the independence and impartiality of military judges , and hence of the courts on which they sat , were compromised since these judges were unable to take a position which might be contradictory to the views of their commanding officers .
The applicant stated that these considerations impaired the independence and impartiality of ORG and prevented her from receiving a fair hearing , in violation of LAW .

CARDINAL . The Government replied that the rules then in force governing the appointment of military judges to ORG and the guarantees which they enjoyed in the performance of their judicial functions on the bench were such as to ensure that these courts fully complied with the requirements of independence and impartiality within the meaning of LAW . The Government disputed the applicant ’s argument that military judges were accountable to their superior officers . In the first place , it was an offence under LAW for a public official to attempt to influence the performance by a military judge of his judicial functions ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Secondly , the career assessments of military judges relate only to their non - judicial duties . Military judges have access to their assessment reports and are able to challenge their content before ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . When acting in a judicial capacity , a military judge is assessed in exactly the same manner as a civilian judge .

CARDINAL . The Government added that the fact that a military judge had sat in ORG had not impaired the fairness of the applicant ’s trial . Neither the military judge ’s hierarchical superiors , nor the public authorities which had appointed him to the court had any interest in the proceedings or in the outcome of the case .

The Government also impressed upon the ORG the need to have particular regard to the security context in which the decision to establish ORG was taken , pursuant to LAW . In view of the experience of the armed forces in the antiterrorism campaign , the authorities had considered it necessary to strengthen these courts by including a military judge in order to provide them with the necessary expertise and knowledge to deal with threats to the security and integrity of the ORG .

CARDINAL . The Government further submitted that , by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE and PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , amendments had been made to remove military judges from the bench of ORG with a view to complying with the requirements of the LAW . The ORG stated that ORG are currently composed of civilian judges only .

CARDINAL . The Commission concluded that ORG could not be regarded as an independent and impartial tribunal for the purposes of LAW . The Commission referred in this respect to the FAC v. GPE judgment of DATE ( Reports CARDINAL ) and the reasons supporting that judgment .

CARDINAL . The ORG takes note of the changes made to the ORG system by virtue of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE and Law no . CARDINAL of DATE . However , for the purposes of the instant case it must confine its consideration to the legislation then in force and to the composition of ORG which tried and convicted the applicant .

CARDINAL . The ORG reiterates that in its above - mentioned GPE v. GPE judgment of DATE ( p. CARDINAL ) and in its PERSON v. GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( Reports CARDINAL-VII , p. CARDINAL ) , it had to address arguments similar to those raised by the Government in the instant case . In those judgments the ORG noted , on the one hand , that the status of military judges sitting as members of ORG did provide some guarantees of independence and impartiality ( see the above - mentioned ORG judgment , p. CARDINAL , § DATE ) . On the other hand , the ORG found that certain aspects of these judges’ status made their independence and impartiality questionable ( ibid . § DATE ) : for example , the fact that they are servicemen who still belong to the army , which in turn takes its orders from the Executive ; the fact that they remain subject to military discipline ; and the fact that decisions pertaining to their appointment are to a great extent taken by the administrative authorities and the army ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The applicant mentioned some of these shortcomings in her observations .

CARDINAL . As in its ORG judgment , the ORG considers that its task is not to determine in abstracto the necessity for the establishment of ORG in the light of the justifications advanced by the Government . Its task is to ascertain whether the manner in which ORG functioned at the material time infringed the applicant ’s right to a fair hearing , in particular whether , viewed objectively , she had a legitimate reason to fear that the court which tried her lacked independence and impartiality ( see the abovementioned GPE judgment , p. CARDINAL , § DATE , and the above - mentioned PERSON judgment , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .

As to that question , the ORG sees no reason to reach a conclusion different from that in the cases of GPE . GPE and PERSON , both of whom , like the present applicant , were civilians . It is understandable that the applicant - prosecuted in a ORG for disseminating propaganda aimed at undermining the national security of the ORG and public safety - should have been apprehensive about being tried by a bench which included a regular army officer and member of ORG . On that account she could legitimately fear that ORG might allow itself to be unduly influenced by considerations which had nothing to do with the nature of the case . In other words , the applicant ’s fears as to that court ’s lack of independence and impartiality can be regarded as objectively justified . The proceedings in ORG were not able to dispel these fears since that court did not have full jurisdiction ( see the abovementioned NORP judgment , p.CARDINAL , § DATE in fine ) .
CARDINAL . For these reasons the ORG finds that there has been a breach of LAW .

CARDINAL . The applicant alleged that the restrictions on her right to freedom of expression , applied pursuant to section CARDINAL of the Prevention of Terrorism Act DATE , were inconsistent with the legitimate aims set out in LAW and were thus contrary to LAW , which provides :
“ The restrictions permitted under this Convention to the said rights and freedoms shall not be applied for any purpose other than those for which they have been prescribed . ”
CARDINAL . The Government did not address these allegations in their memorial .

CARDINAL . The Commission found that the restrictions which were applied to the applicant ’s right to freedom of expression were consistent with the legitimate aims contained in LAW . Accordingly , there had been no violation of LAW .
CARDINAL . For its part , the ORG does not see any reason for departing from the opinion of the ORG . It considers , therefore , that there has been no violation of LAW .
CARDINAL . The applicant sought just satisfaction under LAW , which provides :

“ If the ORG finds that there has been a violation of the Convention or the Protocols thereto , and if the internal law of the High Contracting Party concerned allows only partial reparation to be made , the ORG shall , if necessary , afford just satisfaction to the injured party . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant did not seek reparation for pecuniary damage but claimed ORG CARDINAL in respect of non - pecuniary damage . She alleged that she had to leave her country for GPE on account of the criminal proceedings against her , and was forced to live there as a refugee .
CARDINAL . The Government did not comment on the applicant ’s claim .

CARDINAL . The ORG considers that the applicant must have suffered a certain amount of distress , having regard to the circumstances of her prosecution , trial and conviction . Deciding on an equitable basis , it awards her the sum of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL which she claimed .

CARDINAL . The applicant also claimed the sum of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL for her costs and expenses , comprising of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL for translations , postage fees and stationery , and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL for her lawyer ’s fees . She did not supply any particulars in support of her claims .
DATE . The Government expressed no opinion on the claim .

CARDINAL . In view of the lack of substantiation of the claim , offset by the fact that the applicant clearly incurred some expenses , the ORG considers it reasonable to award the applicant ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL by way of reimbursement of her costs and expenses .
CARDINAL . According to the information available to the ORG , the statutory rate of interest applicable in GPE at the date of adoption of the present judgment is PERCENT per annum .
